<summary>
* The formation process of massive stars is still not fully understood, with observations being challenging due to their distances and clustered mode of formation.
* Recent high-resolution observations suggest massive stars form via accretion, as indicated by the presence of keplerian disks around young stellar objects and a mass-function of protostellar dust clumps close to a salpeter value.
* Methanol maser emission, tracing massive star formation, is found either not associated or offset from Class II regions, hinting at different formation processes or environments.
* Observations in the mid-infrared (mir) window reveal multiple mir sources within the protostellar cores, with cooler extended sources dominating the luminosity and point sources close to the brightest mir source.
* The time scale for a source at the core edge to migrate to the center is comparable to the hot molecular core lifetime, leaving open the possibility of large protostellar motions within the core.
* Monte Carlo simulations show it is difficult to generate the observed mass distributions for the most massive cluster members from the gas in the core using a standard form of the initial mass function ( imf), suggesting a deviation from standard stellar formation processes.
* The findings indicate that the mass distribution of the most massive stars in these clusters cannot be easily explained by a standard imf, implying a need for further study with larger samples of young, massive protoclusters.
* This work was supported by the Australian Research Council and UNSW, with the Gemini Observatory operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under a cooperative agreement with the NSF.
</summary>

• Modified theories of gravity, particularly @xmath0 gravity, have gained attention for explaining the accelerated expansion of the universe, with dark energy being a key component. Researchers are exploring the characteristics of dark energy through these theories, which modify Einstein's general relativity by adding or replacing curvature invariants in the action.

• Lovelock theory and Gauss-Bonnet gravity are examples of such modifications, with the latter being a quadratic curvature invariant that avoids ghost instabilities. These theories are promising for understanding dark energy and cosmic evolution.

• The @xmath0 theory of gravity, which couples curvature and matter, has been used to reconstruct cosmological models like the de Sitter universe, power-law solutions, and @xmath13CDM model. Stability analysis against linear perturbations is crucial for assessing the viability of these models.

• De Sitter and power-law solutions have been reconstructed in @xmath0 gravity, with stability against perturbations being numerically analyzed. De Sitter models show instability, while power-law solutions in the accelerated phase are stable.

• The @xmath0 model that explains both phantom and non-phantom eras of the universe has been reconstructed, but it fails to reproduce the @xmath13CDM cosmology. Stability analysis indicates that the de Sitter and power-law solutions are unstable in @xmath0 gravity.

• The paper concludes that cosmological reconstruction and stability analysis can restrict the applicability of @xmath0 gravity in the context of a Friedmann-Robertson-Walker universe, with the stability of models being determined by perturbations in the field equations and energy-momentum tensor.

• The paper's findings suggest that while @xmath0 gravity can describe certain cosmic histories, it may not be comprehensive enough to account for all cosmological observations, especially the @xmath13CDM model. Further research is needed to refine these theories and their predictions.

• Majorana fermions (MFs) are predicted to occur as quasi-particle bound states in condensed matter systems, and their detection is crucial for applications in quantum computation and information processing.
• Experimental evidence for MFs has been challenging to obtain due to the possibility of other mechanisms causing zero-bias peaks in tunneling spectroscopy experiments.
• An alternative all-optical scheme is proposed to detect MFs in iron chains on a superconducting pb surface using a coupled hybrid quantum dot (qd)-nanomechanical resonator (nr) system with an optical pump-probe setup.
• The qd-nr system is optically probed, and the interaction between MFs and the qd is mainly due to dipole-dipole interaction, which can be adjusted by several tens of nanometers.
• The optical scheme detects MFs signatures via changes in the coherent optical spectrum of the qd, avoiding direct contact and other disturbing signals.
• The role of the nr in the hybrid system is to enhance the exciton resonance spectrum, making MFs more detectable, and the vibration of the nr acts as a phonon cavity.
• The proposed optical scheme provides a new platform for applications in all-optically controlled topological quantum computing based on MFs.
• The authors acknowledge support from various foundations and the key foundation for young talents in college of Anhui province.
• The optical detection scheme is the first all-optical means to probe MFs, and it is based on quantum interference between the nr and the beat of two optical fields via the qd.
• The qd-mf coupling strength can be determined by measuring the distance of the two peaks in the probe absorption spectrum, which follows a nearly linear relationship.
• The proposed scheme could be further improved by embedding a metal nanoparticle-quantum dot complex in the nr to enhance the coherent optical property of the qd.
• The optical detection scheme offers a robust and sensitive method for MFs detection, which is beneficial for future quantum technologies.

<summary>* The first evidence of time reversal symmetry violation in the kaon system has not been found despite extensive searches. * The study of time reversal symmetry is fundamental in the search for physics beyond the Standard Model, with various theories predicting specific violations. * Effective hadronic operators can be parameterized in terms of one boson exchanges, leading to @xmath0-even and @xmath1-odd interactions. * The paper estimates hadronic matrix elements relating quark operators to effective hadronic parameterizations of @xmath0-even @xmath1-odd interactions. * Two generic quark operators are considered, leading to effective @xmath1-odd @xmath0-even vector type and axial vector type exchanges. * The constituent quark model is used to relate quark and hadronic degrees of freedom, assuming the same hadronization mechanism for @xmath1odd and @xmath1even interactions. * The factorization approximation is used to evaluate matrix elements, with results depending on quark model parameters. * The paper concludes that the factors arising reflect nucleon structure effects and could be related to "anomalous" coupling. * The author acknowledges support from the National Institute for Nuclear Theory at the University of Washington. * The paper references several works related to time reversal symmetry, quark models, and effective hadronic operators. * The paper includes a table of values for quark structure effects and a figure illustrating the calculation. * The paper discusses the implications of the results for understanding time reversal symmetry violations in nuclear physics.

• Quantum entanglement, a key resource in quantum information processing, is challenging to quantify in mixed states due to the infinite ways a density operator can be decomposed. The entanglement of formation and entanglement of distillation are measures that address this by evaluating lower bounds, but they struggle with mixed states. The entanglement of formation is zero for certain states that appear as mixed states but are actually pure bell states, while the entanglement of distillation measures the entanglement extractable through local operations and classical communication.

• Nha and Carmichael introduced a measure of entanglement for open systems based on quantum trajectory unravelings, which considers the system's interaction with the environment and the information gained from measurements. This approach reveals the conditional nature of entanglement, showing that it can be contextual and dependent on the observer's knowledge.

• The study examines the conditional evolution of a cascaded qubit system coupled through photon exchange, demonstrating bimodal behavior at resonance. The system either evolves into a maximally entangled bell state or enters an entangled-state cycle, where it stochastically switches between two bell states while emitting photons. This behavior is analogous to a bimodal system in classical statistical physics with a vanishing transition rate between attractors.

• The quantum trajectory approach provides insight into the dynamics of entanglement, showing that the system's evolution can be contextual and dependent on the observer's knowledge. The study suggests that a complete measure of entanglement should consider not only the mixed state but also the process through which it was generated and the access this provides to a conditional dynamics.

• The paper concludes that the density operator alone is insufficient for a complete description of entanglement in open systems. Quantum trajectories offer a way to unravel the system's dynamics, revealing the conditional nature of entanglement and the potential for extracting entanglement through collaboration with an external observer. This approach could lead to a more comprehensive measure of entanglement that accounts for physically realizable unravelings.

• The difference between type 1 and type 2 active galactic nuclei ( AGN) is explained by angle-dependent circumnuclear obscuration of the accretion disk and broad-line region, commonly referred to as the "dust torus."
• Type 1 AGN face-on view exposes the innermost hot dust to the observer, while type 2 AGN's edge-on view blocks the line of sight to the hot dust, leading to stronger infrared (IR) emission in type 1 AGN.
• The paper aims to quantify the wavelength dependence of the anisotropy of AGN emission in the IR from 2 to 8 micrometers using a nearly isotropically selected and complete sample of quasars and radio galaxies.
• The sample comprises all 3CRR radio galaxies and quasars with a lobed radio structure dominated by the AGN, matched in terms of intrinsic luminosity.
• The data show that radio galaxies are systematically lower in IR emission than quasars, with the discrepancy largest in the near-IR part of the spectrum.
• The observed anisotropy ratio between quasars and radio galaxies gradually decreases from 20 to 2 at wavelengths 2 to 8 micrometers, with a mean anisotropy of about 1.4 at 15 micrometers.
• The silicate absorption and emission features in the sample average spectra show a shift in central wavelengths, consistent with previous reports and suggesting a change in dust chemistry within the torus.
• Clumpy torus models are used to test if the observed anisotropy can be explained by the intrinsic anisotropy as predicted in the AGN unification scheme.
• The clumpy torus model reproduces the observed type 1/type 2 ratio reasonably well, with the model parameters suggesting a slightly more centrally condensed and transparent torus.
• The overall small degree of anisotropy is consistent with the torus being clumpy rather than smooth, supporting the intrinsic anisotropy of luminous type 1 and type 2 AGN.

• Continuous-variable quantum key distribution (CVQKD) has seen advancements in both theory and practice, with experimental systems demonstrating secure communication over tens of kilometers.
• Traditional security analyses often overlook the local oscillator (LO), an auxiliary beam necessary for phase reference in homodyne detection, leaving potential loopholes for eavesdroppers.
• This paper explores the impact of LO intensity fluctuations on the security of practical CVQKD systems, proposing an attack that exploits these fluctuations and analyzing the secret key rate under such conditions.
• We find that without monitoring LO intensity or scaling measurements with it, the secret key rate can be severely compromised, allowing an eavesdropper to gain partial or full keys undetected.
• Our analysis shows that even small LO intensity fluctuations can significantly affect the secret key rate, especially in reverse reconciliation over long distances.
• We demonstrate that eavesdroppers can exploit LO fluctuations to hide their attacks, particularly in reverse reconciliation, by adjusting the LO intensity during key distribution.
• To ensure unconditional security, it is crucial to monitor LO intensity fluctuations accurately and scale measurements accordingly, a challenge for practical CVQKD implementations.
• The paper concludes that accurate LO intensity monitoring is essential for confirming the security of practical CVQKD systems and that current implementations may underestimate the secret key rate due to average LO intensity normalization.

• The code aims to compute adiabatic oscillation frequencies and eigenfunctions for general stellar models with emphasis on accuracy, offering flexibility in integration methods and the ability to determine all frequencies within a specified range. It is inspired by previous works and provides extensive documentation for users.

• The equilibrium model is defined using a minimal set of dimensionless variables, mass, and radius, with additional variables for central pressure and density, and scaled second derivatives at the center. The code also allows for the specification of the polytropic index for models with vanishing surface pressure.

• The code solves the equations of adiabatic stellar oscillations using shooting or relaxation techniques, with options for different numerical methods, including a fourth-order integration scheme. It can handle both complete and truncated models, with special considerations for boundary conditions at singular points.

• The code includes techniques to improve frequency precision, such as the variational principle and richardson extrapolation, and can output eigenfunctions in various forms. It also has the potential for further improvements, such as a fourth-order integration scheme and the use of lagrangian pressure perturbation to avoid density discontinuity issues. The code supports the takata classification for dipolar modes and can compute rotational splitting kernels for given rotation profiles.

* The study proposes a new explanation for the formation of hi supershells in spiral galaxies, suggesting they are created by radio jets inflating bubbles in the interstellar medium (ISM). * This jet-ISM interaction model accounts for the observed hi supershells in galaxies like NGC 3556 and NGC 3044, which are too large and energetic to be formed by conventional supernova events. * The model also explains the symmetric distribution of hi supershells and their z-symmetric deviations from spherical symmetry, as well as their correlation with nonthermal radio halos, without the need for massive starbursts or infalling gas clouds.

• Leo I is a dwarf spheroidal galaxy with unique characteristics among local group galaxies, showing a well-populated red clump but no evident horizontal branch, suggesting a delay in the onset of substantial star formation compared to other dwarf spheroidal galaxies. It also has a larger fraction of intermediate-age and young stellar populations, and no significant amount of old population, indicating a more recent star formation history.

• The color-magnitude diagram (cmd) of Leo I reveals a broad main sequence turnoff and red clump, indicating star formation extending from at least 10 billion years ago to less than 1 billion years ago, with no clear discontinuities suggesting a continuous star formation activity. The absence of a prominent horizontal branch and the presence of a dense red clump, along with a range of young yellow stars, suggest that Leo I may have experienced a more recent and continuous star formation history, with possible variations in intensity over time but no major bursts.

* The paper verifies a property of the principal eigenvalue when the classical Laplacian is replaced by the fractional Laplacian, focusing on bounded domains with zero divergence vector fields. The authors use the green function and properties of the heat kernel of gradient perturbations of the fractional Laplacian to define and study the principal eigenpair in the Sobolev space equipped with the Dirichlet form of the fractional Laplacian.
* The main result asserts that if a bounded domain with zero divergence vector field is simply connected, then the infimum of the principal eigenvalue is attained, using Krein-Rutman theorem and compactness arguments. The paper also extends the results to non-local operators and discusses the implications for the flow lines of the vector field.

• The study explores the use of unsupervised machine learning to identify phase transitions in physical systems without prior knowledge of microscopic theories or order parameters.
• Variational autoencoders, an advanced form of autoencoders, are employed to find low-dimensional latent representations of physical systems that coincide with the correct order parameter.
• The reconstruction error from the decoder network is shown to be a promising universal indicator for phase transitions, as it changes drastically at the transition point.
• The study demonstrates the capability of variational autoencoders to handle both discrete and continuous symmetries in phase transition models, such as the ising and xy models.
• The research suggests that deep convolutional autoencoders could be developed to further improve the locality of feature selection and potentially reveal connections with renormalization group theory.

• A "partial" quantum cloning machine (qcm) can be designed to copy only one component of a two-partite quantum state, which is useful for eavesdropping scenarios where only part of the quantum information is of interest.

• The construction of such a qcm for mixed states involves the "purification" of the mixed state and then applying "partial" cloning, with the quality of cloning depending on the initial state and optimized by minimizing a certain integral average of the distance between the initial and output states.

• The nature of dark matter remains a significant question in astrophysics, with cold dark matter models suggesting a major component of elementary particles, but the possibility of a baryonic component due to the shortfall in observed baryons from cosmic microwave background fluctuations.
• Dense gas clouds, such as cold, self-gravitating molecular clouds, have been proposed as a significant baryonic component of dark matter, which could emit gamma rays from cosmic-ray interactions, potentially observable by instruments like the Compton Gamma Ray Observatory.
• Previous calculations often neglected effects like self-shielding and cascade processes, which are significant at high column densities, and used low-density emissivities, potentially affecting the interpretation of the observed excess galactic gamma-ray flux above 1 GeV.
• Detailed calculations using the Geant4 simulation code show substantial differences in gamma-ray spectra between high and low column-density clouds, with the emissivity dropping rapidly at higher densities.
• The gamma-ray spectra from cosmic-ray interactions with dense gas clouds can be used to constrain dark matter models, with the constraint on baryonic dark matter being less stringent than previously thought based on low-energy gamma-ray data alone.
• The constraints from gamma-ray data suggest that the galaxy's dark halo can be entirely baryonic, provided the individual components have a column density of about 1000 g/cm², with higher column densities allowing for all of the dark halo to be in the form of dense clouds.
• The observed gamma-ray excess in the inner galactic disk at high energies suggests that the constraints from low-energy data may be too restrictive, and the actual constraints from gamma-ray data are broader, allowing for a larger fraction of the dark halo to be baryonic.
• The constraints on baryonic dark matter from gamma-ray data are less stringent than previously thought, and the observed gamma-ray excess in the inner galactic disk indicates that the dark halo may not be entirely non-baryonic.

* The study explores the tunability of colloidal crystal lattice constants in a rotating electric field, with potential applications in optical devices.

* They conducted experiments and monte-carlo simulations to measure and predict the lattice spacing in quasi-2D colloidal crystals, using anionic polystyrene latex particles.

* The study concludes that the approach of using effective colloid-colloid interactions can be useful for engineering complex systems with tunable properties.

* The researchers suggest that metal-coated colloids could enable stronger dipolar interactions and lower field strengths for tunability.
* The study's methodology demonstrates the potential of using effective colloidal interactions for modeling complex systems.
* The researchers acknowledge the limitations of their assumptions and the need for more quantitative measurements of local ion concentration.
* The study's findings could have implications for the development of tunable optical devices and materials.

• Aql X-1, a soft x-ray transient, shows properties similar to persistent low mass x-ray binaries and may represent a missing link between low mass x-ray binaries and recycled millisecond pulsars ( msps).
• The quiescent x-ray luminosity of Aql X-1 is likely powered by a radio pulsar, suggesting a transition from the propeller regime to the radio pulsar regime as the transient approaches quiescence.

• A hypernova-like supernova ( sn ) explosion model of a Wolf-Rayet star explains the bolometric and x-ray light curves of sn  2006jc , with the energy source being the @xmath0-@xmath1 decay .
• The model assumes the progenitor star to be a Wolf-Rayet star with a c-rich envelope and circumstellar matter ( csm ) , which is consistent with the formation of amorphous carbon grains in the sn ejecta and the csm .
• The model with @xmath2 , @xmath3 , and @xmath4 best reproduces the bolometric light curve of sn  2006jc , and the temperature evolution of the carbon dust heated by the @xmath0-@xmath1 decay reasonably explains the infrared observations .
• The x-ray light curve is reproduced by the ejecta-csm interaction with a flat csm density profile , which indicates a drastic change of the mass-loss rate and/or the wind velocity two years before the explosion .

* The simultaneous spectral fitting of igr j170913624 during different phases of its ` heartbeat ' oscillations suggests a very low or negative spin for the black hole in this binary system, contrasting with the high spin of the black hole in grs 1915 + 105.
* The spectral fitting results indicate that the distance and accretion rate are well constrained for a given set of system parameters, with the distance being particularly sensitive to the inclination angle and the accretion rate to the black hole mass.
* The observed faintness of igr j170913624 is attributed to its low or negative spin, rather than to its mass or distance, as the spectral fitting does not provide significant constraints on the distance.
* The heartbeat oscillations in igr j170913624 can potentially be used as a standard candle to constrain the black hole's inclination and spin, with the lowest inclination angle being around 76 degrees and the spin being less than 0.2.
* Theoretical implications of a retrograde spin for igr j170913624 are challenging to explain, but the observed spectral and variability characteristics suggest that the accretion process, rather than the black hole spin, is the primary driver of the extreme variability seen in both sources.
* The research utilized data from the HEASARC and GSFC, with acknowledgments to A.R. Rao for discussions and an anonymous referee for comments, and employed tools like XSPEC, XSPEC_FITS, and XSPEC_FITS_PLOT for spectral analysis.

• The extinction curve describes how extinction changes with wavelength and is crucial for understanding the properties of interstellar dust.
• A one-parameter family of curves, characterized by @xmath0, represents the UV to IR extinction law, with @xmath0 varying from about 2.0 to 5.5, indicating different dust properties in diffuse and dense interstellar media.
• The paper extends the method used by gs to compute @xmath0 values for stars with known UV extinction data, introducing weights to account for observational errors.
• The authors present results for 782 lines of sight, showing good agreement between unweighted and weighted methods, and discuss the systematic errors in extinction curve determination.
• They analyze the sky distribution of @xmath0 values, revealing some anisotropy and a mean value of about 3.1, which is consistent with previous findings.
• The paper also examines the effect of different calibrations of @xmath46 on @xmath0 values, finding a significant difference that could indicate a systematic error in @xmath0 determination.
• The authors suggest that future work should extend the study into wavelength regions beyond UV to check the universality of the ccm law.
• They acknowledge the support from the earastargal fellowship and thank colleagues for their helpful suggestions and comments.
• The paper includes detailed data tables and formulae for computing @xmath0 and @xmath1 values, as well as the maximum and error in quadrature for @xmath0.
• The authors conclude by emphasizing the importance of accurate @xmath0 values for understanding the extinction curves and the properties of interstellar dust.

• The rank of a @xmath0-hypergeometric system is a module determined by an integral matrix and a complex parameter vector, with solutions occurring in various mathematical and physical contexts. The rank coincides with the dimension of its solution space at a nonsingular point and is holonomic, meaning it is finite and equal to the dimension of the solution space at a generic nonsingular point.

• The article provides a combinatorial formula for the rank of a @xmath0-hypergeometric system in terms of lattice translates determined by the integral matrix and a complex parameter vector, refining the stratification of the parameter space by the rank of the system. This is achieved by considering weakly toric modules and their associated euler  koszul homology, leading to a geometric stratification of the parameter space.

* The paper proposes a quantum bit (qubit) encoded in the doublet subspace of a triangular quantum dot (tqd) system, with qubit states prepared and manipulated by breaking the system's symmetry using local potential gates.
* A new method for qubit state read-out is introduced, based on the doublet blockade effect, which manifests itself in current measurements and is related to asymmetries in tunnel rates from source and drain electrodes to tqd.
* The dynamics of the qubit, including coherent oscillations and relaxation processes due to electrode interactions, are studied, revealing that the qubit can maintain its spin coherence for times needed for read-out processes, with characteristic times on the order of nanoseconds.

• Symbiotic systems consist of a white dwarf, a red giant, and circumstellar and circumbinary nebulae emitting across a wide frequency range.
• The Z Andromedae system has shown multiple periods of activity, with notable events in 1915, 1939, 1960, 1984, and 2000, characterized by classical outbursts and nonuniform eruptions.
• The 1984-1986 outburst in Z Andromedae is unique due to its double peak structure and exceptionally low brightness, leading to ambiguous interpretations as either a double or a disturbed single outburst.
• Detailed modeling of the uv-optical spectra from 1984-1986 reveals unexpected episodes, suggesting collisions between the white dwarf wind and two ejected shells from the red giant.
• The collision events are characterized by sudden changes in density and shock velocity, with the nebula downstream of the shock front being heated and ionized.
• The ionization parameter drops significantly after June 1985, indicating a shift in the shock front's distance from the white dwarf, likely due to the ejection of a new shell from the red giant's atmosphere.
• The silicate grains' formation time scales suggest that the grains did not have enough time to develop during the collision with the second shell, as they were recently formed.
• The continuum spectral energy distribution (sed) shows that the nebula's emission is mostly in the optical and near-uv frequency range, with bremsstrahlung potentially being the x-ray source.
• The distance of the nebulae from the system center changes during the outburst, with the distance increasing after the collision of the white dwarf wind with the second red giant shell.
• The 1984-1986 outburst's minimum brightness is attributed to the collision of the wind network with a new red giant shell, preventing the black body flux from fully ionizing the nebula.

• The study investigates the frequency and electric field dependent conductivity of single-walled carbon nanotube (swcnt) networks with varying densities.

• The onset frequency extracted from frequency dependence measurements increases with film thickness, while the length scale from electric field dependent measurements decreases.

• An empirical relation between the onset frequency and the nonlinear transport length scale is proposed, showing a linear relationship with a fitting parameter.

• The nonlinear behavior of resistance on electric field strongly depends on film thickness, with thicker films showing nonlinearity at higher electric fields.

• The length scale extracted from electric field dependent measurements decreases with increasing film thickness, indicating that carriers in thicker films have shorter average distances to travel between junctions.

• The onset frequency and the length scale are inversely related, suggesting that thinner films with larger correlation lengths have smaller onset frequencies.

• The mobility of carriers in swcnt networks is estimated to be much smaller than that of individual swcnts, consistent with the observed transport properties.

• The proposed empirical relation between onset frequency and nonlinear transport length scale helps understand the electric transport properties of swcnt films.

• The study concludes that poor inter-bundle junctions in swcnt films affect carrier transport, causing strong thickness dependence of characteristic length scales.

• The onset frequency and length scale are inversely related, and the empirical relation provides insight into the electric transport properties of swcnt films.

• The study highlights the importance of understanding the frequency and electric field dependent conductivity of swcnt networks for applications such as high-speed transistors and transparent shielding materials.

• The research was supported by the University of Maryland and the National Science Foundation.

• The authors thank colleagues for their help and discussions on the work.

• The proposed scheme for implementing three-qubit Grover's algorithm utilizes four-level superconducting qubits (squids) in cavity quantum electrodynamics (QED), offering a faster and more robust alternative to previous methods that require uniform coupling constants and slow adiabatic changes. The scheme avoids the need for level spacing adjustments and uses resonant and off-resonant interactions, which are less sensitive to decoherence. It also simplifies the implementation by employing a three-qubit phase gate instead of a series of two-qubit gates, reducing error probability.

• The scheme accounts for imperfections such as spontaneous decay and cavity field decay, which can affect the fidelity of the quantum gates and the success probability of the algorithm. The study shows that high fidelity and success probability can still be achieved with small decay rates, and the algorithm can perform with high fidelity even in the presence of imperfections. The estimated operational time for the three-qubit phase gate is in the order of nanoseconds, making the implementation significantly faster.

• The proposed scheme is robust against non-uniform device parameters and does not require direct coupling between specific levels, allowing for longer storage times of qubits. The fast pulses used in the scheme may introduce new imperfections, but the overall performance remains high as long as the decay rates are sufficiently small. The scheme is an advancement in the field of quantum computation using superconducting qubits and cavity QED, demonstrating the potential for practical quantum algorithms in superconducting systems.

* The many-body effects on XPS spectra in metals, particularly the appearance of singularities near edges, have been a topic of interest since the 1970s.
* Non-adiabatic excitation in metals leads to shake-up effects, analogous to water waves in a glass, resulting in plasmon replicas in the spectrum and a low-energy tailing characteristic of metallic systems.
* In graphene, a 2D system, collective excitations (2D plasmons) contribute to the tailing even without distinct plasmon replicas, complicating the interpretation of XPS spectra.
* This work derives the core-hole spectra for 2D systems and presents numerical results for pristine and doped graphene, showing that pristine graphene exhibits low-energy tailing, a metallic characteristic.
* Doping in graphene alters the tailing of the XPS peak, with significant changes observed at doping concentrations exceeding a certain threshold.
* Theoretical XPS spectra for graphene are compared with experimental data, showing good agreement and suggesting a method to estimate doping levels using spectral tailing.
* A formalism is introduced to include both lorentzian and gaussian broadening effects, enhancing the practical applicability of the theoretical model.
* The study acknowledges the contribution of experimental data from various research groups, which helped validate the theoretical results.
* The work builds on previous models for core-hole problems and exciton annihilation in quantum wells, adapting them to the unique properties of graphene.
* The findings indicate that a full calculation of core-hole spectra in graphene is necessary for accurate interpretation, rather than relying on traditional fitting methods.
* The research provides a comprehensive understanding of the XPS spectra in graphene, which could aid in the development of graphene-based technologies and materials science.

• The study explores the impact of nonlinear frequency-dependent selection and asymmetric mutation probabilities on the coevolutionary dynamics of a two-genotype system using the moran process, revealing that these factors can induce multiple stable states and complex dynamics.

• The researchers derived a stationary probability distribution for the system using the fokker-planck equation, showing that asymmetric mutation rates can lead to the emergence of new stable points or the disappearance of existing ones, and that nonlinear fitness functions can result in multiple stable points.

• The study concludes that in real biological systems, multiple metastable equilibria may exist due to complex interspecies interactions, potentially causing sudden shifts in population frequencies without environmental changes.

* The phase-field method is a popular tool for simulating microstructure formation during solidification due to its algorithmic simplicity and ease of coding.
* The method's equations can be straightforwardly written but require detailed mathematical analysis to understand their properties fully.
* The thin-interface limit is a crucial concept for eliminating finite interface thickness effects in simulations, but not all thin-interface effects can be removed.
* Orientation-field models for polycrystalline solidification are inadequate as they fail to account for the connectivity of matter and geometrical conservation laws.
* Microscopic fluctuations in phase-field equations are challenging to incorporate accurately, as they require renormalization and careful control of discretization effects.
* The standard approach of adding noise to phase-field models to simulate nucleation is problematic due to the renormalization of field equations by fluctuations.
* The phase-field method's dual nature as a representation of condensed-matter systems and an efficient simulation tool necessitates a balance between theoretical understanding and practical application.
* Future research directions include developing robust models for polycrystalline solidification, addressing the limitations of current phase-field approaches, and exploring new perspectives from phase-field crystal approaches.
* The paper aims to stimulate discussions and solutions to current challenges in phase-field modelling, highlighting the importance of mathematical analysis in understanding and improving simulation accuracy.
* The authors acknowledge the contributions of various colleagues for discussions on phase-field modelling and related topics.
* The paper concludes that the further development of the phase-field method is an exciting research topic at the intersection of physics, mathematics, and materials science.

• The paper presents a new methodology to derive accurate atmospheric parameters of late-type stars using high-resolution spectroscopy, addressing non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (nlte) effects.
• The methodology utilizes the balmer line method for effective temperature, nlte ionization balance of iron (fe) lines for surface gravity and metallicity, and restricts fe lines to those with excitation potentials above 2 eV to minimize 3d effects.
• A comparison with standard stars using interferometric measurements and 1d local thermodynamic equilibrium (lte) methods reveals significant systematic biases in lte-fe estimates, particularly at low metallicities.
• The new nlte-opt method shows less stars on the red giant branch and more in the middle or lower part of the red giant branch, aligning more closely with stellar evolution models.
• The differences in effective temperature, surface gravity, and metallicity between nlte-opt and lte-fe estimates increase with decreasing metallicity, with discrepancies reaching up to 400 K, 0.5 dex, and 0.1 dex, respectively.
• The paper emphasizes the importance of a reliable effective temperature scale, suggesting that the balmer line method is currently the most reliable among available methods.
• The study concludes that accurate spectroscopic determination of stellar parameters is crucial for understanding the chemical and dynamical properties of the Milky Way's stellar populations and for calibrating distance scales.
• The authors acknowledge the contributions of various collaborators and observatories that facilitated the observations and discuss the implications of their findings for the broader field of stellar astrophysics.
• The paper is part of a series aiming to develop robust methods for determining stellar parameters, with the first paper focusing on metal-poor stars from the RAVE survey.
• The research was supported by various grants and acknowledges the role of interferometric measurements in validating the balmer line effective temperature scale.
• The authors suggest that the systematic biases in lte-fe estimates could impact the identification of different components in the Milky Way's halo and the measurement of abundance gradients.

• The study examines the effects of weak gravitational lensing on the observed fluxes of supernovae type Ia ( snia) at high redshifts, using the Anglo-Australian Planetary Search ( apm) galaxy catalog as tracers of foreground mass density.
• The analysis uses 50 snia with redshifts ranging from 0.1 to 1.0, and compares their observed magnitudes and ranks among control regions of apm galaxies to detect lensing-induced amplifications or de-amplifications.
• A significant anti-correlation between snia magnitudes and galaxy counts is found, with a slope of -0.3 for angular radii of 5-15 arcmin, indicating that brighter snia are found behind regions with higher foreground galaxy density.
• The results are robust against variations in the parameters defining the control regions and the galaxy magnitude limits, suggesting that the observed anti-correlation is not an artifact of the analysis method.
• The study also considers the possibility that the observed anti-correlation could be due to galactic dust obscuration, but finds that the effect of dust is unlikely to explain the results, as the average extinction for the snia sample is only 0.18 mag.
• The study investigates how the observed anti-correlation depends on the mass distribution and galaxy biasing schemes, and finds that larger optical depths and broader galaxy mass distributions result in steeper slopes.
• The study concludes that weak lensing of standard candles provides a cleaner probe of the mass distribution on scales of a few megaparsecs, and that snia can be used to measure mass inhomogeneities using gravitational lensing.
• The study also discusses the potential impact of weak lensing on the determination of global cosmological parameters using snia standard candles, and finds that the observed anti-correlation does not significantly bias the derived values of the cosmological parameters.
• The study suggests that a large uniform set of intermediate redshift snia, such as those that would result from the Snap and LSST missions, would be invaluable for studying mass clustering in the nearby universe using weak magnification and weak shear lensing techniques.

* The local moment approach ( LMA) provides a non-perturbative framework for studying the dynamical and transport properties of paramagnetic heavy fermion ( hf ) metals, focusing on the strongly correlated kondo lattice regime. The LMA captures the essential physics of hf metals, including the universal scaling behavior across a wide range of interaction strengths and temperature scales, and the crossover from coherent fermi liquid to incoherent single-impurity kondo scaling.
* The LMA results for d.c. resistivity and optical conductivities in hf metals reveal a universal @xmath0-dependence, independent of interaction strength and hybridization, reflecting the low-energy coherence scale characteristic of the kondo lattice regime. The resistivity shows a peak at low temperatures, indicative of the coherent fermi liquid state, which diminishes and transitions to incoherent scaling at high temperatures.
* The optical conductivities exhibit a drude peak at low temperatures, which broadens and merges into an optical pseudogap at higher temperatures, with the pseudogap's properties depending on the conduction band filling and @xmath3-level asymmetry. The optical pseudogap's behavior is similar for both hf metals and kondo insulators, reflecting the underlying universal low-energy scale governing their optical properties.

* The kinetics of polymer loop formation, including dna loop formation, is a subject of renewed interest due to its biological significance in processes like genetic expression and protein folding.
* Recent studies using single molecule techniques have shown that mechanical forces, such as tension and torsion, play a crucial role in dna loop formation.
* The cell interior, being an active and nonequilibrium medium, exerts fluctuating forces on dna, affecting its loop formation.
* Brownian dynamics simulations combined with the theory of barrier crossing have been used to study the effects of static and fluctuating tension on polymer looping.
* The simulations reveal that even a small tension as low as 100 femtonewtons can significantly increase the looping time, especially for longer chains.
* For time-dependent tension, the looping time shows a resonant minimum at an optimum flipping time, a phenomenon akin to resonant activation in single particle systems.
* The effect of time-dependent tension is more pronounced for longer chains, suggesting that biopolymers may self-organize optimally using ambient nonequilibrium fluctuations.
* The study's findings are consistent with recent experimental observations of dna loop formation under static and fluctuating tension conditions.
* The research opens up possibilities for further experimental studies to establish resonant activation phenomena in polymer loop formation.
* The study also suggests that hydrodynamic interactions, which were previously considered significant, may have a minor effect on the looping time for shorter chains.
* The research contributes to a basic understanding of the physical mechanism of biopolymer looping in the presence of various forces.
* The study's results could potentially lead to a unifying conceptual framework for the diverse experimental observations of dna loop formation.
* The paper concludes that further detailed theoretical and experimental work is needed to fully understand the complex process of biopolymer looping.
* The research highlights the importance of considering the cellular environment's nonequilibrium nature in studying biopolymer dynamics.
* The study's findings have implications for understanding the fundamental principles of biopolymer behavior in living systems.

* The study investigates tidal interactions in binary systems, focusing on the evolution of stars and their impact on orbital parameters over time scales of up to 10^8 years for systems with short orbital periods.
* Three types of stars with masses of one, one and a half, and two solar masses were considered, with their evolutionary stages from protostar to main sequence, and the corresponding changes in their internal structures.
* The overlap integrals, which measure the intensity of tidal interactions, were calculated for each star at various lifetimes, revealing significant changes in tidal forces as the stars evolved from completely convective to having both convective and radiative cores.
* The study found that planets with a mass of one jupiter mass and an initial orbital period of 2 days or less around stars with one and a half or two solar masses will likely fall onto the star within the main sequence lifetime of the star, a result that differs from previous studies that did not account for stellar evolution.
* The research highlights the importance of considering stellar evolution in dynamical tide calculations, as it can lead to drastically different outcomes for the orbital evolution of planets in close binary systems.
* The findings have implications for understanding the fate of exoplanets in short-period orbits around solar-type stars, with potential applications to systems like the hot Jupiter YBP 1194 around a solar twin.

* The paper introduces a new method to measure the relative distance between two incoherent point sources in a scattering medium by analyzing intensity fluctuations in the speckle pattern they produce.
* The method relies on the correlation between the intensity fluctuations and the complex density of states ( cdos ) in the medium, which encodes the distance between the sources.
* The approach could simplify green's function retrieval techniques by replacing two-point field-field correlations with a single-point intensity noise measurement, potentially useful at visible or near-infrared frequencies.
* The paper also suggests that multiple scattering, often considered a nuisance, can enhance the performance of sensing, imaging, and communication techniques by encoding information in the speckle pattern.

• The paper extends the glassy wormlike chain (GWLC) model to account for inelastic deformations in biopolymer networks, focusing on reversible inelastic behavior where the microscopic state returns to its original equilibrium after deformation. The model incorporates a dynamic bond fraction that evolves according to bond breaking and formation rates, influenced by an external force. This approach allows the study of nonlinear mechanical responses in biopolymer networks, such as strain/stress stiffening, fluidization, and cyclic softening.

• The model predicts that for strong deformations, the bond fraction changes significantly, leading to material properties that differ from the typical viscoelastic behavior. It introduces a fluidization response upon strong deformations, where the material exhibits a pronounced softening or inelastic shake-down effect. The yield force for fluidization is found to be sensitive to the deformation rate, and the model predicts a cyclic softening effect after repeated deformation cycles.

• The paper also discusses the implications of spatial heterogeneity in biopolymer networks, suggesting that a distribution of entanglement lengths can smooth out the force-displacement curves without altering their qualitative features. The role of prestress in cells is considered, with the model predicting that increased prestress leads to a higher yield force for fluidization, which is in contrast to the observed correlation between prestress and cell stiffness. The paper concludes by emphasizing the potential for future work to extend the model to irreversible plastic deformations and to compare predictions with experimental data for cells and in vitro biopolymer networks.

* The study examines the stability of topological Mott insulators (TMIs) on the honeycomb lattice against competing orders like charge-density waves (CDWs).
* It is found that long-range CDWs are more stable than TMIs in standard honeycomb lattice models, leading to the dominance of CDWs over TMIs.
* To stabilize TMIs, the fermi velocity at the Dirac cones must be reduced, which can be achieved by introducing third neighbor hoppings in the honeycomb lattice.
* The variational Monte Carlo (VMC) method is used to study the effects of on-site and off-site Coulomb interactions on the stability of TMIs.
* The VMC results show that TMIs are robust against quantum fluctuations and can be stabilized by tuning fermi velocity and controlling Coulomb repulsion.
* Realization of TMIs in real materials like twisted bilayer graphene (TBG) is proposed, where fermi velocity can be tuned by changing the stacking angle between layers.
* Effective Coulomb repulsion in TBG can be suppressed by choosing dielectric substrates, making TBG a potential platform for TMIs.
* The study suggests that adatoms can be used to further screen Coulomb repulsions and stabilize TMIs by placing them on top of carbon atoms.
* The excitation gap induced by TMIs is estimated to be substantially larger than room temperature, supporting the feasibility of TMIs in carbon-based materials.
* The authors acknowledge financial support from the Japan Science and Technology Agency (JST) and discussions with T. Misawa and D. Tahara.
* The paper concludes with the potential of TBG and adatoms in realizing TMIs and the need for further experimental and ab initio studies.

* The study predicts the existence of topological gapless edge states along the recently imaged ab-ba tilt boundary network in gated bilayer graphene, solving the puzzle of sub-gap conductance.
* The proposed topological edge states are protected by time reversal symmetry, absence of valley mixing, and electron number conservation, classifying chirally stacked gated multi-layer graphene as a time-reversal symmetric topological insulator (TSI).
* The study suggests that the tilt boundaries could be the first experimentally observed crystalline topological defects hosting topologically protected gapless transport, potentially explaining the observed sub-gap transport in bilayer graphene.
* The paper proposes experiments to test the transport through the tilt boundary network, including four-terminal transport measurements and scanning tunneling spectroscopy, to confirm the existence of gapless edge states.
* The findings could enable control over sub-gap transport in gated multi-layer graphene systems, opening doors to device applications.

• Macromolecules with ionizable groups in polar solvents dissociate into charged macromolecules and counterions, classified as polyelectrolytes or polyampholytes based on the acidic/basic nature of their monomers.

• Polyelectrolytes and polyampholytes have various industrial and medical applications, with biological macromolecules like DNA, RNA, and proteins also being charged polymers.

• The behavior of polyampholyte brushes depends on the sequence of charged monomers, with oppositely charged monomers attracting and reducing chain size, while the same sign monomers repel and increase chain size.

• The properties of anchored polymer brushes are influenced by the chains' flexibility, charge distribution, and bending energy, with simulations showing different conformations at varying grafting densities.

• For flexible polyampholyte brushes, the average thickness linearly depends on grafting density, with the strength of this dependence being weaker than for semiflexible and rodlike chains.

• Histograms of equilibrium conformations for flexible brushes show weak inter-chain correlations, indicating that single-chain behavior dominates, and the dependence on grafting density is weak.

• In contrast, semiflexible and rodlike brushes exhibit strong dependence of conformations on grafting density, with chains separating into two coexisting fractions at high densities due to electrostatic and excluded volume correlations.

• A simple scaling method is used to describe the linear dependence of brush thickness on grafting density for flexible brushes, with the slope of the linear function varying with system parameters.

• The scaling method is not consistently applicable for semiflexible and rodlike brushes, as their kuhn length exceeds their contour length, but the linear dependence of thickness on grafting density persists across a wide range of system parameters.

• The study demonstrates that despite differences in chain flexibility and sequence of charged monomers, the average thickness of polyampholyte brushes linearly depends on grafting density.

• The findings contribute to understanding the behavior of charged polymer brushes, with implications for industrial and bi

* The light flavor scalar mesons present a challenge for the naive quark model, with structures not yet unambiguously determined. * Some candidates are thought to be glueballs, molecular states, or tetraquark states, with different dynamics below and above certain thresholds. * The scalar mesons below a certain threshold may form tetraquark states, while conventional nonets have masses around 1.2 GeV/c^2. * The strong attractions between diquark states in certain channels may result in tetraquark states below the threshold, while conventional nonets lie in the same mass region. * We construct color singlet tetraquark currents with scalar diquark fields and perform qcd sum rules to study nonet scalar mesons. * The qcd sum rules are new because they use interpolating currents from basic diquark fields instead of quark and gluon fields. * The scalar diquarks are taken as point particles and described with colored diquark fields, overcoming the difficulty of obtaining borel windows for multiquark states. * The new qcd sum rules for nonet scalar mesons are derived, and numerical results are presented and discussed. * The masses and pole residues of the nonet tetraquark states are compatible with experimental data and theoretical estimations. * The scalar tetraquark currents may have non-zero couplings with scattering states, but these contaminations are expected to be small. * The study provides a new spectroscopy for mesons and baryons, and the results can be extended to study other multiquark states. * The work is supported by the national natural science foundation of China and the fundamental research funds for central universities.
</summary>

<summary>* The paper discusses the application of pseudo - transient continuation (PTC) method in power system long-term stability analysis to accelerate simulation speed and overcome numerical difficulties. * PTC method follows the solution of dynamical systems accurately in early stages and sacrifices temporal accuracy to quickly converge to steady state, making it efficient for long-term stability analysis. * The method is particularly useful when the system has complex features like discontinuities, avoiding convergence to nonphysical solutions or stagnation. * The paper modifies the PTC method to implement it in both long-term stability models and quasi-steady-state (QSS) models, ensuring initial conditions are consistent. * Numerical examples demonstrate that PTC method can provide correct stability assessments and overcome numerical difficulties in QSS models, with significant speed improvements over traditional methods. * The PTC method is shown to be a good middle ground between accurate integration and direct steady-state calculation, offering a viable alternative for power system long-term stability analysis. * The paper concludes that PTC method can successfully capture both stable and unstable behaviors in power systems, providing a fast and accurate tool for long-term stability analysis. * The work was supported by the U.S. Department of Energy's Consortium for Electric Reliability Technology Solutions. * The authors acknowledge contributions from various IEEE transactions and journals, as well as previous works on PTC and QSS models. * The paper's methodology and findings are expected to benefit the field of power system stability analysis and simulation.

<summary>
* The study focuses on the 2d quantum scattering of unpolarized dipoles on a long-range anisotropic potential, which is significant for understanding exotic quantum systems and phenomena in condensed matter physics.
* The method developed for this analysis extends previous work on dipole-dipole scattering in three dimensions and is applied to two-dimensional scenarios.
* The method involves representing the wave function as a Fourier series expansion in an angular grid, with the interaction potential incorporated into a diagonal matrix in this grid representation.
* The scattering problem is reduced to a system of coupled ordinary differential equations, which are efficiently solved using fast implicit matrix algorithms like the sweeping method or lu decomposition.
* The method's efficiency is demonstrated through calculations on a cylindrical potential with an elliptical base and on 2d dipole-dipole scattering, showing convergence to analytical results.
* The scattering amplitude is calculated for various potential barriers, including circular and elliptical bases, with high accuracy for different degrees of anisotropy.
* The method provides a powerful tool for studying quantum scattering in two dimensions, with potential applications in creating and understanding exotic quantum systems and materials.
* The computational scheme and convergence details are provided in appendices, with the method's efficiency validated through numerical examples and tables.
* The work contributes to the broader understanding of quantum scattering processes in two-dimensional systems, with implications for both fundamental physics and potential technological applications.
</summary>

<summary>
• G65.2+0.7, initially overlooked after its identification as a supernova remnant, has become interesting again due to its relevance in explaining thermal composite supernova remnants (TSNRs), which exhibit both shell-like radio continuum and centrally bright x-ray emission from thermal processes.
• The remnant's characteristics align with the thermal composite classification, as it has a shell-like radio morphology and centrally filled x-ray morphology, with temperature peaking at the center and decreasing mildly with radius.
• Previously, G65.2+0.7 was not recognized for its full extent, but optical emission line surveys revealed a larger elliptical outline, and radio frequency data suggested a shell-type remnant.
• The remnant's age, estimated at 250 years, and its location in the Milky Way's disk, make it a prime candidate for studying the evolution of TSNRs.
• _ROSAT_ observations confirm the remnant's extended, centrally filled x-ray morphology and a temperature gradient, supporting its classification as a TSNR.
• The remnant's x-ray emission is slightly harder than the surrounding x-ray emission, consistent with the behavior of other TSNRs.
• The remnant's ambient density is lower than that of the archetypal TSNR, w44, which explains its lower luminosity compared to w44.
• The remnant's systemic velocity was used to search for potential interactions with molecular clouds, but inconclusive results were found due to confusion with galactic material.
• The research utilized data from the High Energy Astrophysics Science Archive Research Center (HEASARC) and was supported by NASA's Long Term Space Astrophysics Grant (NASA Grant NAG5-10807).
• The authors express gratitude to the National Research Council, NASA, and the anonymous referee for their support and comments on the research.
• The researchers acknowledge the use of _ROSAT_ data and the support from NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center.
</summary>

* The paper explores succinct encoding of permutations and their applications, focusing on the interplay between sorting algorithms and data compression techniques.
* It introduces a new perspective by relating the difficulty measures of adaptive sorting algorithms to entropy measures for permutation compression, highlighting the utility of concepts like runs and shuffled upsequences in both domains.
* The authors present several encoding schemes for permutations that use @xmath0 bits for easy classes and @xmath1 bits for more complex classes, supporting operations in time @xmath2.
* They demonstrate the application of these compression schemes to various scenarios, including integer functions, text indexes, and self-indexes, achieving significant space savings and efficient operation times.
* The paper also extends the results to represent permutations as cycles, which can be compressed using the techniques discussed, and to integer functions, supporting their application and iterated variants efficiently.
* The authors suggest that the concepts of runs and shuffled upsequences could be generalized to more complex permutations, and that entropy measures could be applied to other data structures like suffix arrays and forests.
* The paper concludes by emphasizing the potential for further research in generalizing these results to more complex permutations and other data structures, and in exploring the relationship between adaptive algorithms and data compression.

* The paper investigates chimera states in networks of non-locally coupled Hindmarsh-Rose (HR) oscillators, a model for neuron dynamics.
* Chimera states, characterized by coherent and incoherent oscillators coexisting, are identified in both 2D and 3D HR models.
* The study reveals that chimera states can occur with different coupling schemes, including direct and cross-coupling of both membrane potential and ionic current variables.
* A novel mixed oscillatory state (MOS) is discovered, where desynchronized neurons are interspersed among those oscillating in synchrony or at rest.
* In the 3D HR model, chimera states appear when coupling is restricted to the membrane potential variable, with spiking occurring within sufficiently long bursting intervals.
* The paper concludes that chimera states in coupled bistable elements are significant for neuroscience applications, and the existence of MOS states is also noted.
* The study contributes to the theoretical understanding of chimera states, extending their occurrence beyond oscillator models with a single limit cycle attractor.
* The authors acknowledge support from the European Union and Greek national funds for their research.
* The paper suggests that future work could explore chimera and MOS states in networks of HR oscillator populations.
* The research highlights the relevance of chimera states in complex systems and the importance of nonlocal coupling in realistic neuron models.
* The paper emphasizes the potential of chimera states to explain unihemispheric sleep in animals and their implications for understanding brain dynamics.

• Kauffman networks, modeled after genetic regulatory systems, have attracted interest due to their resemblance to disordered systems in statistical mechanics, such as spin glasses. These networks exhibit a dynamical phase transition, which has been studied using mean field theory.
• The paper introduces the concept of relevant elements, which are subdivided into asymptotically non-communicating, independent modules, and explores their probability distribution.
• The study reveals that the number of relevant elements scales as @xmath0 on the critical line, and the average length of cycles in networks with @xmath44 relevant elements increases almost exponentially with @xmath44 when @xmath56 is large.
• The average weight of the attraction basins shows a non-monotonic behavior as a function of the number of relevant elements, and the distribution of these variables appears to have a well-defined probability density in the infinite size limit.
• The paper also discusses the limitations of the annealed approximation and proposes a new approximation scheme that works better in the frozen phase and on the critical line, which is the most interesting region in parameter space.
• The authors plan to further investigate the modular organization of the relevant elements on the critical line in their next paper, as it has implications for understanding the statistical properties of the attractors in Kauffman networks.

* The study investigates spin-superflow turbulence ( sst ) in a spin-1 ferromagnetic spinor Bose-Einstein condensate ( bec ) at zero temperature, revealing the presence of both @xmath0 and @xmath1 power laws in the energy spectra of superflow kinetic and spin-dependent interaction energy.
* Theoretical and numerical analysis suggests that the @xmath0 power law in sst arises from the nonlinear spin term, unlike in classical turbulence ( ct) where it originates from the inertial term.
* Numerical simulations confirm the presence of the @xmath0 and @xmath1 power laws in the energy spectra, with the @xmath0 power law sustained over time and the @xmath1 power law persisting even as the energy injection scale increases.
* The study also explores the possibility of an inverse energy cascade in sst, noting that while the superflow kinetic energy exhibits a direct energy cascade, the spin-dependent interaction energy may show an inverse cascade, although the direction of energy cascade for the latter is not yet fully understood.

• We report millimetre survey and submillimetre data analyses for 20 low - luminosity active galactic nuclei ( llagns ) with compact radio cores detected by very - long - baseline - interferometry ( vlbi ) . 
 • Our observations reveal that at least half of the llagns show inverted spectra between 15 and 96  ghz . 
 • Submillimetre fluxes measured with the submillimetre common user bolometer array ( scuba ) on the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope ( jcmt ) may be from the dust associated with host galaxies , and are useful to estimate dust contamination in our nma measurements . 
 • We confirm little diffuse contamination in the nma measurements from dust , free , and extended nonthermal emissions for llagns showing inverted spectra . 
 • We find an inverse correlation between the high - frequency radio spectrum and the low - frequency radio core power in our sample of 20 llagns . 
 • The existence of the adaf ( advection - dominated accretion flow ) will give radio astronomers a chance to make the direct imaging for accretion discs . 
 • Our findings encourage further llagn surveys at higher - frequency ranges with, e.g., the coming Atacama Large Millimetre/submillimetre Array ( alma ) to prove the adaf .

• The study proposes three methods to measure the dust extinction law slope ( @xmath0) in the direction of differentially-reddened galactic globular clusters using cluster color - color diagrams ( cmds ) and star - by - star variations in relative visual extinction across the cluster .
• The methods are tested on simulated cluster data sets and applied to the low-latitude galactic globular cluster ngc  4833 , revealing an @xmath0 value of @xmath7 for the cluster direction.
• The angular power spectrum of dust in the direction of ngc  4833 is estimated from the width of the cluster s blue horizontal branch ( hb ) and matches the larger - scale power spectrum derived from the schlegel et al. ( 1998) infrared space observatory ( iso) and cosmic background explorer ( cobe)/diffuse infrared background experiment ( dirbe ) dust map.

* The paper investigates the fermi surface topology in the kondo lattice model (klm) across a quantum critical point (qcp) in heavy fermion systems, focusing on the competition between kondo screening and Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yosida (rkky) interactions.
* Detailed dynamical cluster approximation (dca) calculations are performed, including the effects of antiferromagnetic order, to map out the magnetic phase diagram as a function of kondo coupling and conduction electron density.
* The study reveals that kondo screening persists even in the antiferromagnetic ordered state, and the fermi surface topology changes from hole pockets around @xmath0 to those centered around @xmath1, without any kondo breakdown.
* The transition within the antiferromagnetic phase is continuous and associated with the backfolding of the heavy fermion band, and the fermi surface topology change corresponds to two lifshitz transitions, with the total volume of hole pockets remaining constant.

• The recent discovery of the Higgs boson at the LHC has implications for understanding particle mass and its role in gravity, particularly in models with nonminimal Higgs-gravity coupling. This coupling could influence inflation and dark energy, and bounds on the Higgs-gravity interaction are sought through astrophysical observations.

• Observations of carbon-rich white dwarfs, like bpm 27606 and procyon b, provide a controlled environment to search for Higgs-induced mass shifts in atomic and molecular spectra. The stability of vibrational transitions in the swan bands suggests that any mass shift would affect electronic transitions, offering a potential signature of Higgs-curvature coupling.

• The analysis of spectral lines from white dwarfs allows for the estimation of upper bounds on the Higgs-curvature coupling, with the current bounds being significantly more stringent than those from LHC experiments. These bounds are crucial for models where the Higgs field influences cosmological phenomena.

• Future improvements in this spectroscopic methodology could lead to even tighter constraints on Higgs-curvature coupling, especially if scalar fields with larger compton wavelengths are considered. This could complement bounds from cosmic background radiation analysis and other tests of gravitational interactions.

• White dwarf (WD) stars represent the end points of stellar evolution for low-mass stars, with more than 97% of all stars in our galaxy expected to become WDs.
• About 80% of WDs belong to the DA spectral class, and when they cool to the appropriate temperature, they enter the ZZ Ceti instability strip, where global pulsations become observable.
• The ZZ Ceti instability strip has been mapped in temperature and surface gravity, but the temperature at which pulsations shut down has been challenging to estimate.
• The discovery of pulsating extremely low-mass (ELM) WDs has extended our understanding of WD pulsations to cooler temperatures and lower masses.
• Two new coolest pulsating ELM WDs, sdss j161431.28 + 191219.4 and sdss j222859.93 + 362359.6, have been found, bringing the total number of known pulsating ELM WDs to five.
• These WDs are likely the product of binary evolution, as the galaxy is not old enough to produce such low-mass WDs through single-star evolution.
• The discovery of pulsations in these ELM WDs challenges the purity of the instability strip for helium-core WDs and suggests that not all ELM WDs will necessarily pulsate.
• Theoretical models predict a blue edge for WD pulsations, which has been confirmed by the discovery of pulsations in cooler WDs.
• The existence of non-pulsating ELM WDs between the newfound pulsating ELM WDs and the classical CO-core ZZ Ceti stars suggests that WD evolution through the instability strip may not be straightforward.
• The discovery of pulsating ELM WDs offers an opportunity to constrain physical and evolutionary models of ELM WDs, particularly the late thermal pulses and the mass boundary for these episodes.

• The interstellar medium (ISM) of disk galaxies is divided into hot ionized, warm neutral, and cold neutral phases, with star formation correlated with molecular gas content.
• Molecular gas, crucial for tracing star-forming regions, is influenced by non-linear processes like self-gravity, stellar feedback, turbulence, and radiation fields, making simulations challenging due to the vast range of spatial scales.
• Recent simulations with supernova feedback and non-equilibrium chemistry show the importance of radiative shielding in determining molecular abundances, but often use simplified, untested approximations for shielding.
• This study compares different local approximations for radiative shielding against full solutions of the radiative transfer equation, focusing on their impact on molecular abundances and temperature.
• The study uses post-processing of supernova-driven galactic disk simulations, employing frequency-dependent radiative transfer and a physically motivated spatial distribution of stellar sources, to compute the equilibrium chemical and thermal state of the disk.
• Various local approximations for radiative shielding, such as the sobolev approximation, jeans length, density gradient, and single-cell shielding, are compared to the detailed ray-tracing method, revealing that the six-ray approximation performs best in matching the molecular abundances of the fiducial model.
• The study finds that self-shielding by molecular hydrogen (H2) is the dominant mechanism for H2 shielding, while dust shielding is critical for carbon monoxide (CO) formation, with both being necessary for significant molecular abundances.
• The study concludes that while radiative shielding is essential for molecular abundances, the exact prescription for local shielding length is less critical, with the six-ray approximation providing a good balance between accuracy and computational efficiency.
• The research highlights the importance of considering both self- and dust shielding in simulations of molecular gas formation and suggests that future multidimensional simulations should continue to refine radiative shielding approximations for improved accuracy.

• The vertical extension of the red clump ( vrc) in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) color-magnitude diagram (cmd) has been interpreted as an intervening stellar population, but evidence suggests it originates from the LMC itself.
• The vrc, seen in all LMC fields, corresponds to the blue loops experienced by intermediate-mass stars in the core helium-burning phase, not a foreground population.
• The vrc's color and brightness are consistent with the blue loops' time-averaged locus in the cmd, indicating a relatively long-lived phase in the stellar evolution of younger core helium-burning stars.
• The relative stellar density of the vrc is consistent with the density on the main sequence and the assumption of continuous and constant star formation in the LMC over the past 1 billion years.
• Stellar evolutionary models, assuming a Salpeter initial mass function (IMF) and constant star formation rate, can account for nearly the full extent of the vrc's stellar density.
• The vrc feature is also present in the Hipparcos color-magnitude diagram of the solar neighborhood, further supporting its origin in the LMC.
• The vrc's position and color are not significantly affected by small variations in the LMC's distance modulus, indicating that the LMC's luminosity and color are well-represented in the models.
• The vrc's presence in the LMC cmd is not due to a burst of star formation, as younger isochrones provide a better fit to the red clump than older ones.
• The vrc's color insensitivity to age for stars between 400 and 1 billion years old is consistent with the observed color of the red clump in the LMC and the solar neighborhood.
• The vrc's position and color are not significantly affected by small variations in the LMC's reddening, indicating that the LMC's color and brightness are well-represented in the models.
• The vrc's presence in the LMC cmd is not due to a new foreground population, as the LMC's main sequence and red clump are well-represented in the models.
• The vrc's presence in the LMC cmd is

• The study uses data from the Wide-Field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) to investigate the star formation in 69 galaxy clusters, focusing on the fraction and specific star formation rates (sfr) of star-forming galaxies out to 3 times the virial radius. The research finds that while the fraction of star-forming galaxies increases with projected distance from the cluster center, it remains below the field value even at large radii, suggesting that star formation is suppressed in a significant population of galaxies in small groups or filaments before they are accreted into clusters.

• The study also examines the relationship between cluster mass and total cluster star formation rate (sfr), finding no significant correlation between the two, which implies that cluster mechanisms that scale with cluster mass, such as ram pressure or harassment, do not play a dominant role in the evolution of star formation in local clusters. This suggests that strangulation may be a key process in quenching star formation in cluster star-forming galaxies, regardless of cluster mass.

* The paper investigates the strong bishop-phelps-bollobs property (sbpbp) for bounded linear operators between Banach spaces, focusing on conditions that Banach spaces must satisfy for the sbpbp to hold. It introduces the sbpbp for operators, which requires that for any Banach space and any compact operator, there exists a vector in the domain space where the operator attains its norm.

* The paper provides examples of Banach spaces that fail the sbpbp, both in the uniform case and when the sbpbp depends on a fixed operator, and gives a complete characterization of the sbpbp for certain pairs of Banach spaces.

• The frozen nucleon approximation significantly simplifies the calculation of inclusive two-particle-two-hole (2p-2h) responses in relativistic fermi gas models for neutrino scattering, reducing the number of required integrals from seven to one.
