<summary>* The Children, Young People and Education Committee welcomed Kirsty Williams, Cabinet Secretary for Education, and Eluned Morgan AM, Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning, to discuss the impact of Brexit on higher and further education. * Suzy Davies inquired about the preparedness of Welsh universities for a 'no deal' Brexit scenario, to which Kirsty Williams and Huw Morris responded that the Welsh Government has been working closely with higher education and further education institutions to understand potential impacts and refine approaches. * The Higher Education Funding Council for Wales has been conducting specific work on risk assessments, while individual institutions are encouraged to develop their own plans. * Eluned Morgan AM highlighted the importance of the European Social Fund (ESF) and apprenticeships, with a focus on maintaining these programs post-Brexit. * The European transition team, led by Marie Knox, coordinates Welsh Government's work on European transition, including discussions with the UK government and other departments. * Welsh Government is committed to implementing the Diamond and Reid reviews, with a focus on sustainable funding for higher and further education. * The Welsh Government has been working to maintain EU funding for apprenticeships and is seeking assurances beyond 2020. * The Welsh Government is collaborating with other departments to understand the impact of Brexit on employability and skills needs. * The committee will meet in private to discuss the papers and continue the meeting next week.

• The Welsh Government is considering charging international fees for HE students in a 'no deal' scenario, but this would be curtailed if reciprocal arrangements with the EU were established.
• Welsh Government officials are continuing to push for a favorable immigration system for EU and international students, aiming to keep them out of immigration targets and ensure their ability to study in Wales.
• Welsh Government officials are working with other departments to understand the broader impact of Brexit on employment and the economy, and to ensure that the FE and HE sectors can respond to employer needs.
• The Welsh Government is developing a policy on rural skills and has committed PS10 million to support the FE sector in responding to workplace demands, with a review of FE funding also underway.
• Welsh Government officials are confident that the current discussions and actions are constructive and positive, with a focus on maintaining and expanding employability and skills training in response to employer needs.

• Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education, discussed the targeting of Pupil Development Grant (PDG) funding, emphasizing that while individual interventions should be for free school meal eligible children, schools may use PDG for universal interventions if they demonstrate a disproportionate benefit for those children.

• Williams expressed confidence in the current eligibility criteria for PDG, stating it's the best measure we have, though she acknowledged ongoing discussions with local government about potential alternative measures.

• She mentioned the consideration of greater flexibility in PDG allocation, with thoughts on longer-term projections to aid schools in planning, but noted the financial constraints preventing an Ever 6 system.

• The effectiveness of PDG in improving educational outcomes for free school meal pupils was discussed, with Williams noting improvements in attendance and narrowing of the attainment gap, though acknowledging the need for further strategies to address persistent challenges.

• The role of leadership, systems, and collaboration in school improvement was highlighted, with Williams asserting that the lessons from Schools Challenge Cymru are being applied to the wider school improvement agenda, ensuring continued support for schools beyond the program's timeframe.

They discussed the remote's main function of changing channels and considered making it a universal remote that could control various electrical products. Ideas included a spherical design with grips for easy handling, a keyboard-like shape for one-handed operation, and a flat bottom with grips for stability. <summary>
• Professor B and PhD E discuss the informal nature of meetings and the need for a formal report on the Aurora project, highlighting the competitive atmosphere and the realization that French Telecom Alcatel and their team were not as collaborative as initially thought.
• The conversation reveals that the voice activity detector was a significant point of contention, with the team having worked on it for months without disclosing it to others, leading to claims of unfairness when it was later discovered by competitors.
• Despite the disagreement on the endpointing data requirement, the team agrees to discuss the issue further, with Nokia and Qualcomm advocating for maintaining the fifty percent improvement criterion.
• Professor B expresses concern that the test criteria may be flawed due to arbitrary decisions and the lack of comfort among participants in the decision-making process.
• The team is working on noise separation and exploring the use of temporal pattern recognition (TRAPS) for speech recognition, with the goal of achieving significant improvements in recognition accuracy.
• The discussion concludes with the team planning to meet again to discuss progress and the possibility of achieving the fifty percent improvement, while also considering the challenges of latency and the need for alternative solutions if the current system cannot comply with the new criteria.
• The team reflects on the personal motivations of team members, such as the incentive for Pratibha to pursue a PhD, and the broader implications of the Aurora program for the future of speech recognition research.
</summary>

<summary>• John Griffiths appoints John Griffiths as temporary Chair for today's meeting. • Dr David Blaney and Bethan Owen from the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales present evidence on Brexit's impact on higher and further education. • EU student applications to Welsh institutions have decreased by 8%, contrasting with a 2% increase in England. • Welsh universities face funding pressures, student recruitment challenges, and potential pension cost increases. • The Welsh Government's HE Brexit working group assesses risks and potential impacts of Brexit on the sector. • Welsh universities are exploring various scenarios and preparing for potential changes, including maintaining research capacity and student mobility. • The sector is seeking additional funding sources and working on marketing Wales internationally. • Welsh universities have student charters and protection measures in place, but Brexit raises concerns about EU student immigration status. • Welsh universities need to continue investing in research to maintain quality and competitiveness in UK-wide research funding. • The sector is working on attracting charitable sector research funding, but overhead costs remain a barrier. • The committee will discuss the Welsh Government's draft budget and other papers in private session.

<summary>
• The Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed the principles for reopening schools in Wales, emphasizing safety, well-being, clear communication, and operational feasibility, with no imminent changes to current restrictions.
• The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams, highlighted the importance of following medical and scientific advice, maintaining public health measures, and working with education and FE sectors, including universities, to address the challenges of remote learning and support for vulnerable and special needs students.
• The committee also discussed the impact of the pandemic on examinations, with Qualifications Wales providing a process for awarding grades based on teacher assessments and the need for universities to support students financially and academically during the crisis.
</summary>

<summary>• Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, emphasized the importance of health and well-being in decisions about reopening schools, stating that decisions will be based on advice from medical and scientific advisers and will consider the safety of children, young people, and staff. She clarified that a return to normal education is not imminent and that any decisions will be communicated clearly to parents and staff to build confidence and allow for planning.
• The Minister highlighted the need for practical considerations in reopening schools, such as workforce availability, social distancing, and avoiding gatherings at school gates. She also mentioned the importance of testing, tracing, and quarantining in the next phase of education.
• The Minister confirmed that the principles for reopening schools also apply to further education and universities, and that discussions with the higher education sector are ongoing to address their unique challenges.
• Concerns were raised about the safety of vulnerable children in school settings, and the Minister assured that local authorities and schools are working to assess and support these children, including those with additional learning needs.
• The Minister discussed the importance of mental health support for children during the pandemic, and the allocation of PS1.25 million for school counselling, with plans to increase services as needed.
• The Welsh Government is working with local authorities to ensure that children have access to necessary technology for remote learning, and is considering the distribution of equipment and connectivity to those in need.
• The Minister addressed the issue of examinations, stating that A-level and GCSE results will be awarded based on teacher assessments and that universities are working to support students affected by the pandemic.
• The Minister discussed the impact of the pandemic on higher education, including the release of funds to support institutions and the continuation of student support payments for those who have returned home.
• The Minister and her officials thanked the committee for their time and will be sent a transcript for accuracy checking.
• The committee resolved to meet in private for the remainder of the meeting.

• The committee resolved to meet in private for the remainder of the meeting to continue the discussion.
